The Heroes takes place in the same world as the First Law Trilogy, just slightly from now on of those happenings. Many of that characters from old First Law novels appear although the whole story is often a dissection of some three-day battle relating to the fields surrounding this town of Osrung.
;
;May well Abercrombie gives us another fantasy booklet about passion, scary and war. It is heroic military wonderland at its top. He manages to do one of the hardest things; he brings the characters to life. In the Heroes we get to be a part of the fight instead of just reading about it. He might not certainly be a Geppetto (Pinocchio's father) but as a result of weaving together inner monologues with usb actions he gives the narrative an wonderful immediacy, like it's happening the following and right now.
;
;This Heroes is written in a interesting way. Right from the first showdown scene the storytelling technique is revealed. Joe Abercrombie takes a particular man's viewpoint and additionally follows him right until he's killed. The story then jumps towards the killer who we travel to follow until he's mortally wounded, and so upon. We get that you should follow what's going on in the man's head as soon as his breathes are generally counted. How does it feel knowing that you'll probably die inside of seconds? Does it hurt to find run through with a blade or shot using a crossbow?
;
;Certainly one of Abercrombie's, in my estimation more brilliant, ideas the e-book is revolving around is that you can learn all you have to know about a people by how this individual fills the distance between what he really wants to be and what he actually is. And if it's filled with corpses, what will that say? Of which you're a leading man? So many fellas have heroism in their brain but not on their hearts. The idea of fame and glory overshadows the truth of killing as well as being killed.
;
;Probably Joe Abercrombie's other points could be the meaninglessness of warfare. The land the location where the battle takes place aren't worth considerably, there's no precious metal or riches, just soon being destroyed crops. There's no real reason for fighting. The purpose with the fight in the Heroes is always to finish it as quickly as possible just so which other fights are usually fought elsewhere. I realize, it seems pointless, but so will most wars when you start to take into consideration it.
;
;A Heroes is ultimately a bit darkish and grim, but furthermore honest and comical. Believe it and also not, human tragedy is usually comical. Joe Abercrombie's people that pursue heroism with a wrongful notion as well as single-minded persistence will end up being deluded on their experience of lifestyle, unless they are too entitled or narcissistic to be able to that their popularity only were dreamed of.
